line_first: abs quivis homine, quom est opus, beneficium accipere gaudeas;

comments_on_length: 254-255, 287 and Ctesipho’s lines in general, many res; but note longs for frater frater (256) and Aeschinus (260), festivom caput (261) ipse exit foras (264), 268 fratrem: o mi Aeschine, o me germane! ah (268-269); 277 longs for ego a forum ibo ut hunc absolvam
comments_other: Ctesipho praises brother; AE rebukes CT, SA taken care of; back to ia8: same for AE, CT, SY, opposed to tr7 and ia6 of SA

line_first: accedo, rogito Pamphila quid agat, iam partus adsiet,

comments_other: explanation of CA’s accusation; AE can’t tell truth for fear of revealing brother; starts accedo, rogito Pamphia quid agat…;  quoting Canthara; ia8 for AE and for CA: both have been ia8 before

comments_on_length: lines very regular (551-555 completely regular); resolution for hercle tibi istam (Amph.) at 556; extra long for linquam abscidam (Amph.) at 557; resolution for quidque facias (Sos) at 558; resolution for ego hodie (Amph.) at 563; for ludificati (Amph.) at 565; extra longs for tun id dicere audes, quod nemo umquam homo antehac/ vidit (566-67, Amph.); more extra longs and resolutions in 570-571 (ba4 ending); longs in 560 reflect determination; extra resolutions in 570-571 reflect extra heat in exchange
comments_other: bacchiacs for luggage carrying, arrival, argument; Sosia, carrying luggage, tries unsuccessfully to convince Amphitruo that he was at door; ends with question

z_old_text: DA. audi obsecro.  DR. quid vis? SI. sublimem intro rape hunc, quantum potest. DR. quem? SI. Davom.  DA. quam ob rem?  SI. quia lubet.  rape inquam.  DA. quid feci? rape. DA. si quicquam invenies me mentitum, occidito.  SI. nil audio.
comments_on_length: no res in 861, few in 862-863
comments_other: Davos pleas to be heard and insists he is telling the truth; starts with Davos’ audi and ends with Simo’s nil audio;  another set of 2-3 ia8, as we have seen several times above

line_first: cura adservandum vinctum, atque audin? quadrupedem constringito.
line_last: cura adservandum vinctum, atque audin? quadrupedem constringito.
z_old_text: cura adservandum vinctum, atque audin? quadrupedem constringito.
closure: per end of thought last before ia6
comments_on_length: almost all longs

line_first: perii! verum hercle opinor fuisse Phaniam; hoc certo scio,
line_last: CH. proviso quid agat Pamphilus.  atque eccum.  PA. aliquis fors[itan; me putet
z_old_text: perii! verum hercle opinor fuisse Phaniam; hoc certo scio    SI. age fiat. PA. at matura. SI. eo intro. PA. o faustum et felicem diem!
comments_on_length: 929 almost all longs
comments_other: starts as Crito responds to name Phania: (OCT attributes these lines to Crito, notes confusion over speakers in app. crit.); continues through anagnorisis, release of Davus; ends with entrance of Charinus (his first line is ia8)

line_first: quid ais? quom intellexeras
line_last: quid ais? quom intellexeras
z_old_text: SI. quid ais? quom intellexeras
comments_on_length: an sp tr long
comments_other: shorter trochaic for questioning

line_first: numquam quoiquam nostrum verbum fecit neque id aegre tulit.
line_last: at nunc faciet neque, ut opinor, sine tuo magno malo.
z_old_text: numquam quoiquam nostrum verbum fecit neque id aegre tulit. SI. at nunc faciet neque, ut opinor, sine tuo magno malo.
closure: per end of speech end of aside
comments_on_length: Davus starts with string of spondaic 2-syllable words: 178 all spondees until 6th an, 7th tr; Simo eavesdropping; keeps same meter; his meter is sp an an sp tri sp tr long: his anapests (anger? irony?) contrast with Davus’ spondees of wondering; in fact Davus has very few resolutions in 175-178 (just 3); whereas Simo has 3 in one line
comments_other: Davos finishes, Simo, eavesdropping, responds; switch to tr for extra emotion, but Davus precedes with his tr; but his is little different from ia, with all its spondees

line_first: prorsus a me opinionem hanc tuam esse ego amotam volo.
line_last: hoc nisi fit, puerum ut tu videas, nil moventur nuptiae.
z_old_text: prorsus a me opinionem hanc tuam esse ego amotam volo....   hoc nisi fit, puerum ut tu videas, nil moventur nuptiae.
comments_on_length: 511: longs for audivi et credo; 512 longs for qui coniecturam hanc nunc facio; 512 longs for inventumst falsum.  nunc, postquam videt; 515-516: resolutions
comments_other: Davus reports his “speculations” on what is going on; starts with “I don’t want you to think that about me”; tr7 for core of story: note this is important information

line_first: id consilium capere, quor non dixti extemplo Pamphilo?
line_last: immo abi intro: ibi me opperire et quod parato opus est para.
z_old_text: id consilium capere, quor non dixti extemplo Pamphilo?...   SI. immo abi intro: ibi me opperire et quod parato opus est para.—
comments_on_length: 519 res and elision for quis igitur eum ab illa abstraxit nisi ego? nam omnes nos quidem; res and difficulty (3 tribrachs) in 522 for command: perge facere ita ut facis, et id spero adiuturos deos.
comments_other: Davus finishes explanation, says he drove Pamphilus from girl, exits

line_first: sati’ iam sati’, Simo, spectata erga te amicitiast mea;
line_last: SI. Dromo, Dromo.  DA. quid est? SI. Dromo.  DA. audi.  SI. verbum si addideris...! Dromo.
z_old_text: sati’ iam sati’, Simo, spectata erga te amicitiast mea;...   SI. Dromo, Dromo.  DA. quid est? SI. Dromo.  DA. audi.  SI. verbum si addideris...! Dromo.
comments_on_length: 820 sati’ iam sati’ metrically parallel;  831 eiu’ labore atque eiu’ :metrically parallel: Chremes waxing rhetorical;  832 short phrases;  844 an an an sp tr sp tr
comments_other: Simo and Chremes argue, Davos caught coming out of Glyc’s house; then says someone says Glycerium is Attic citizen;  starts with Chremes rebuking Simo; ends with Simo fetching Dromo to bind Davos;  everything set up in ia6, then it happens in tr7

line_first: DR. ego iam te commotum reddam.  DA. tamen etsi hoc verumst? SI. tamen.
line_last: DR. ego iam te commotum reddam.  DA. tamen etsi hoc verumst? SI. tamen.
z_old_text: DR. ego iam te commotum reddam.  DA. tamen etsi hoc verumst? SI. tamen.
closure: per end of thought change of addressee
comments_other: tr7 for Dromo’s threat

line_first: ego me amare hanc fateor; si id peccarest, fateor id quoque.
line_last: CR. is ibi mortuost.  CH. ei(u)s nomen?  CR. nomen tam cito?  Phania? hem
z_old_text: PA. ego me amare hanc fateor; si id peccarest, fateor id quoque....   CR. is ibi mortuost.  CH. ei(u)s nomen?  CR. nomen tam cito?  Phania? hem
comments_other: continues through entrance of Crito; ends as Crito reveals name of girl’s father (Phania); exclamation ends tr7 and starts ia8;  Again Crito enters (904) without changing meter

line_first: poeta quom primum animum ad scribendum adpulit,
line_last: futuras esse audivit.  sed ipse exit foras.
z_old_text: poeta quom primum animum ad scribendum adpulit,...   (SIM) futuras esse audivit.  sed ipse exit foras.
comments_other: prologue; exposition with protatic charcter

line_first: si sensero hodie quicquam in his te nuptiis
line_last: aut velle in ea re ostendi quam sis callidus,
z_old_text: si sensero hodie quicquam in his te nuptiis fallaciae conari quo fiant minus, aut velle in ea re ostendi quam sis callidus,
comments_other: warning to Davus: si sensero hodie...; pause before warning; protasis in ia6, apodosis in ia8; discussion of this change in Bruder 42-43, with bib.: “Diese Warnung ist das Kernstück der Szene”, leads to whole comedy; switch back to ia8 at 199 gives threat comic effect

line_first: reviso quid agant aut quid captent consili.
line_last: nunc hui(u)s periclo fit, ego in portu navigo.
z_old_text: reviso quid agant aut quid captent consili....  nunc hui(u)s periclo fit, ego in portu navigo.
comments_other: Si mon; Byr hears Pamphilus agree to marriage; Si questions Davus; Simo hears birth; eavesdropping; progress of plot; complex discussion; call offstage of childbirth; ends with short Simo mononologue

line_first: credon tibi hoc nunc, peperisse hanc e Pamphilo?
line_last: DA. teneo quid erret et quid agam habeo.  SI. quid taces?
z_old_text: credon tibi hoc nunc, peperisse hanc e Pamphilo? DA. teneo quid erret et quid agam habeo.  SI. quid taces?
comments_other: two-liner: silence important; peperisse echoes announcement of ia6 486; tacere in ia6 after ia8; echoes 486 (that was announcement, this is response)

line_first: non inpulit me haec nunc omnino ut crederem;
line_last: atque adeo in ipso tempore eccum ipsum obviam.
z_old_text: non inpulit me haec nunc omnino ut crederem;...   atque adeo in ipso tempore eccum ipsum obviam.
comments_other: Simo mon: I am not sure what to believe; what’s important is that son agreed to marriage; thoughtful monologue

line_first: SI. iubeo Chremetem... CH. o te ipsum quaerebam.  SI. et ego te.  CH. optato advenis.
line_last: SI. ausculta pauca: et quid ego te velim et tu quod quaeris scies.
z_old_text: SI. iubeo Chremetem... CH. o te ipsum quaerebam.  SI. et ego te.  CH. optato advenis. aliquot me adierunt, ex te auditum qui aibant hodie filiam meam nubere tuo gnato; id viso tune an illi insaniant. SI. ausculta pauca: et quid ego te velim et tu quod quaeris scies.
comments_on_length: 532: elision at end of each of individual speech: eagerness in greeting; 535: shorts for marriage; hiatus after illi?
comments_other: starts with greetings between Simo and Chremes; ends SI. Ausculta pauca: et quid ego te velim et tu quod quaeris scies.

line_first: per te deos oro et nostram amicitiam, Chreme,
line_last: merito te semper maxumi feci, Chreme.
z_old_text: per te deos oro et nostram amicitiam, Chreme,...   SI. merito te semper maxumi feci, Chreme.
comments_other: Sim explains that he wants fast marriage; Chremes agrees reluctantly; music stops for request; central moment of plot in ia6; major speech act: plea

line_first: age nunciam: ego pol hodie, si vivo, tibi
line_last: SI. Chreme?  CH. at tandem dicat.  SI. age dicat, sino.
z_old_text: age nunciam: ego pol hodie, si vivo, tibi...  SI. Chreme?  CH. at tandem dicat.  SI. age dicat, sino.
comments_other: Sim has Dav dragged off, calls Pamphilus; Simo chews out Pamphilus;  crisis moment;  ends as SI. lets PA speak (age dicat, sino);  Simo’s anger at DA and PA joined;  Bruder 44: ia6 gives seriousness to threat

line_first: poeta quom primum animum ad scribendum adpulit,
line_last: futuras esse audivit.  sed ipse exit foras.
z_old_text: poeta quom primum animum ad scribendum adpulit,...   (SIM) futuras esse audivit.  sed ipse exit foras.
comments_other: prologue; exposition with protatic charcter

z_old_text: perlecebrae, permities,

line_first: sicine hoc fit?  foras aedibus me eici?
line_last: bene merenti mala es, mala merenti bona es,
z_old_text: sicine hoc fit?  foras aedibus me eici? promerenti optume hoccin preti redditur? bene merenti mala es, mala merenti bona es,
comments_on_length: 2 completely regular lines; then resolutions for: bene merenti mala es, male merenti bona es,
comments_other: Argyrippus to Cleareta: am I thus thrown out?; opening of canticum; 1st two lines are independent questions

line_first: ibo ego ad tres viros vostraque ibi nomina
line_last: faxo erunt, capitis te perdam ego et filiam,
z_old_text: ibo ego ad tres viros vostraque ibi nomina faxo erunt, capitis te perdam ego et filiam,
comments_on_length: res. for vostraque ibi, capitis
comments_other: Argyrippus to Cleareta: threatens to take them before tresviri

line_first: nam mare haud est mare, vos mare acerrumum;
line_last: quae dedi et quod bene feci, at posthac tibi
z_old_text: nam mare haud est mare, vos mare acerrumum; nam mari repperi, hic elavi bonis. ingrata atque inrita esse omnia intellego quae dedi et quod bene feci, at posthac tibi
comments_on_length: 134, reg. ex. short before diaeresis, 135 hiatus at diaeresis, long for hic elavi; 136 long for ingrata atque, 137 short before diaeresis, longs for feci at posthac
comments_other: Argyrippus to Cleareta: you are more voracious than sea; what I gave and did well is all unappreciated, at posthac tibi….

line_first: perfidiae laudes gratiasque habemus merito magnas,
line_last: ARG. bene dicite.  LI. ite intro cito. ARG. valete.— LE. et vos amate.—
z_old_text: perfidiae laudes gratiasque habemus merito magnas,...   ARG. bene dicite.  LI. ite intro cito. ARG. valete.—LE. et vos amate.—
comments_other: Libanus and Leonida triumph; money to Argyrippus after he is humiliated; echoes 381ff.; 549/550 one line; Leo brackets 547, 552, 570, and 573, but I have counted them all; Leo places a 1-verse lacuna after 553, which I have counted (Lindsay has just 4 verses between 550 and 555)

line_first: numquidnam tibi molestumst, gnate mi, si haec nunc mecum accubat?
line_last: ARG. em istoc me facto tibi devinxti.  DE. quin te ergo hilarum das mihi?
z_old_text: numquidnam tibi molestumst, gnate mi, si haec nunc mecum accubat?...   ARG. em istoc me facto tibi devinxti.  DE. quin te ergo hilarum das mihi?
comments_other: Aryrippus. and Demaenetis with Philaenium; Argyrippus must accept father’s wishes; 839-840 and 849-850 are one verse each

line_first: male quod potero facere faciam, meritoque id faciam tuo.

line_first: perii interii occidi! quo curram? quo non curram? tene, tene! quem? quis?
line_last: oro obtestor, sitis et hominem demonstretis, quis eam abstulerit.
z_old_text: Euclio’s panic; plea to audience
comments_on_length: surprising number of spondees given his excitement; 713: 3 anapests with 2 elisions (1 anapest per word) get things started fast: perii interii occidi!; then spondees as he ponders what to do: quo curram? quo non curram? Then 4 shorts for tene, tene! (thrust forward) then spondee for quem? quis? (pause for questioning); 714: dactyls start: despair (nescio, nil video), then more anapests with elisions and a hiatus (caecus eo atque equidem quo eam aut ubi sim aut qui sim; 715: starts anapests again (nequeo cum animo); then spondees for uncertainty (certo investigare) then anapests as he turns to audience (obsecro vos ego mi auxilio); 716: longs for plea, with 4 shorts in middle, anapests at end: oro obtestor, sitis et hominem demonstretis, quis eam abstulerit; 719: shorts for quid est? then more spondees as he responds to audience’s laughter: quid ridetis? novi omnes, scio fures esse hic complures; 717: more longs for accusation: qui vestitu et creta occultant sese atque sedent quasi sint frugi; 718: more shorts as he turns to individual: quid ais tu? tibi credere certum est, nam esse bonum ex voltu cognosco
comments_other: Euclio’s panic; plea to audience; Questa puts 719 between 716 and 717

comments_on_length: starts rather spondaic (727a-728); then more shorts as he recognizes Euclio and says oppido interii etc. (728-729); spondaic for initial uncertainty (nunc mi incertumst, 729a), then many shorts for deliberation (abeam an maneam an adeam an fugiam; / quid agam edepol nescio, 730-730a); 730 and beginning of 730a are heavily anapestic, echoing Euclio’s anapest, then trochee to end; hiatus after agam
comments_other: Lyconides’ first words after Euclio’ s panic; switch to tr7 for Lyconides: plot will move again; Lyconides’ anxiety and uncertainty; includes 727a, 728a, 729a, 730a  (7 tr4 and 1 tr4cat to close)

line_first: PH. etiam tu, homo nihili? quod dei dant boni cave culpa tua amissis;

comments_on_length: note increase in short syllables, especially at 1189/90 for Nic.’s indignation, and 1191: age iam, id ut est, etsi est dedecori, patiar, facere inducam animum; 1192: Ba, in her eagerness to reassure Ni, elides his last word, then elides diaeresis; cf. 1177, where Phil. does same thing as he is seduced; repetition emphasizes Nic’s reluctance vs. Phil.’s eagerness
comments_other: Nicobulus gives in, in conversation with PH.; 1189/90 one line 1190 : again, significant ending from Phi: potandumst

line_first: NI. quid ago? PH. quid agas? rogitas etiam? NI. libet et metuo.  BA. quid metuis?
line_last: BA. hanc veniam illis sine te exorem.  NI. ut terebrat! satin offirmatum

BA. quid metuis? completely anapests, until Bacchis speaks and introduces line’s final dactyl; 1197ff: more longs as BA. takes control; 1199: elision and change of speaker at diaeresis;
comments_other: Nicobulus’ emotion?; an7 starting unit again: Nic. question at an7; cf. 1154, 1156, 1160, 1176; other an7 here start 1149: Ba decides to seduce, 1169: Ph:non homo tu es; 1181: Ba: i hac mecum intro; 1187; Ph.: etiam tu, homo nihil? 1199: Nic’s last attempt at resistance echoes meter of Ph’s eager seduction at 1177 and Ba’s promise at 1192: elision over speaker, anapest

comments_other: Nicobulus says enough of your banquet business and complains of being duped; Nicobulus keeps introducing these an systems; what does me nil paenitet ut sim acceptus mean?; Barbsy says problematic, prob. ironic;  3 an4 + 1 an4cat; there are 1182 a-b

line_first: hoc est demum quod percrucior,
line_last: miserum me auro esse emunctum.
z_old_text: hoc est demum quod percrucior, / me hoc aetatis ludifica-/ ri, immo edepol bis ludos factum; / cano capite atque alba barba / miserum me auro esse emunctum.
comments_on_length: almost all spondaic; note especially string of spondees at end: miserum me auro esse emunctum.; one anapest or dactyl per line; just under 13% 2-shorts, only one dactyl in whole section; slowing down for biggest mourning; back to slows of beg.
comments_other: new system starts in middle of his hoc complaints, for last one (demum) (4 an4 + final an4cat); 1099a, 1100, 1100a, 110a, 1101a; parallels Philoxenus’ 1084ff., break to ansys10 with many spondees

line_first: solus ego omnes longe antideo
line_last: quae meus filius turbavit.
z_old_text: Nic. on how stupid he was
comments_on_length: dactylic openings to 1st 2 lines; note indignant longs in 1090-1090a; anapests at 1091 for magis id reputo; ending 3 longs of turbavit
comments_other: Nic. on how stupid he was; switch to system as he turns from list of fools to himself (solus ego) (5 an4 and 1 and4cat at end); each verse has corresponding “a” verse; note contrast with Phil: Phil kept 8 verses of long an8 and an7, then went to a very spondaic ansys; Nic. just keeps an7 for 2 verses, then to system filled with an and dactyls

line_first: alterum tantum auri non meream.
line_last: malo illos ulcisci ambo.
z_old_text: Nicobulus continues threat against Chrysalus; Bacchis promises half of money; Nicobulus refuses to forgive Chry. and Mne.
comments_on_length: 1185a: PH. has anapest: faciet; 1186-1187: Nic. has shorts for minime… and moror sine sic; then all longs for concluding: malo illos ulcisci ambo; ;
comments_other: Nicobulus continues threat against Chrysalus; Bacchis promises half of money; Nicobulus refuses to forgive Chry. and Mne.l enjambment before; system starts for conclusion of I will get Chrysalus, then continues through promise and refusal; 5 an4 + 1 an4cat; there are 1184a, 1185a, 1186a 1184a: no meter change for Ba’s proposal to give 1/2 of money back; 1185a: Ph with significant end of verse again (cf. 1162, 1163); 1186: Ni’s anapest minime immediately after Ph.’s anapest faciet

line_first: caput prurit, perii, vix negito.

z_old_text: NI. caput prurit, perii, vix negito. / BA. non tibi venit in mentem, abamo, / si dum vivas tibi bene facias / tam pol id quidem esse haud perlonginguum, / nec, si hoc hodie amiseris, post in / morte id eventurum esse umquam?
comments_on_length: shorts continue; 1193a: Ba. produces her second hiatus in 3 lines; each comes before amabo (1192: te amabo; 1193a: mentem amabo); calling attention to love?; 1194: note shorts of tibi bene facias; 1195: spondee at conclusion, as at 1186a
comments_other: system starts as NIC fears giving in, continues through carpe diem; 5 an4 + 1 an4cat; each verse has “a” verse

line_first: alterum tantum auri non meream.

comments_other: Nicobulus continues threat against Chrysalus; Bacchis promises half of money; Nicobulus refuses to forgive Chry. and Mne.l enjambment before; system starts for conclusion of I will get Chrysalus, then continues through promise and refusal; 5 an4 + 1 an4cat; there are 1184a, 1185a, 1186a 1184a: no meter change for Ba’s proposal to give 1/2 of money back; 1185a: Ph with significant end of verse again (cf. 1162, 1163); 1186: Ni’s anapest minime immediately after Ph.’s anapest faciet

comments_other: bouncier wilamowitzians reflect Pistoclerus’ attempt to cheer; first line ends have repeated anapests perii (627 taceam), with change of speaker before last anapest; then Mnesilochus takes over completely at 628 (echoing rhythm of Pistoclerus’ opening [626]); when Pistoclerus tries again to reassure him, Mnesilochus interrupts him even earlier, for whole last choriamb (elision suggests interruption?) (630), then continues another line; Pistoclerus continues with new topic—driving away of parasite—and he manages more than one line; each line has corresponding “a” line

line_first: SEN. egone in lustra? CL. scio plus quam tu me arbitrare.  SEN. quid id est? quid [tu] scis?
line_last: CL. mades mecastor: vide palliolum ut rugat!  SEN. di me te infelicent
z_old_text: SEN. egone in lustra? CL. scio plus quam tu me arbitrare.  SEN. quid id est? quid [tu] scis? CL. te sene omnium se<num homi>nem neminem esse ignaviorem. unde is, nihili? ubi fuisti?  ubi lustratu’s? ubi bibisti? mades mecastor: vide palliolum ut rugat!  SEN. di me te infelicent
comments_on_length: 244: heavily trochaic for te sene omnium senum hominem neminem esse ignaviorem; 245: shorts for ubi’s in questions; each of three ubi’s is on ictus, as is initial unde; hiatuses after nihili and fuisti set off 1st 2 questions; 246: shorts on ictus for mades and vide, then longs for di me et te infelicent
comments_other: SEN. and CL.; she has string of accusatory questions, he has simple what do you mean questions

comments_other: Ol. enters fleeing “Casina”; echoes anapests of SEN’s 1st entrance (217)?

comments_other: Ol annoyed with SEN, says he smells; an8 end anapestic section, start smell part

line_first: operam date, dum mea facta intero: est operae pretium auribus accipere,
line_last: sed tamen tenebrae ibi erant tamquam in puteo; dum senex abest, ‘decumbe’ inquam.
z_old_text: opera date. beg. of report
comments_on_length: 879: all anapests except mea facta (could this not also be anapest?); elision over diaeresis and sentence end (itero: est operae); 880-882: more spondees, but 2 anapests at beginning of both 880 and 881, 6 consecutive shorts near beginning of 882 (sed tamen tenebrae ibi); 880: hiatus at diaeresis and later (quae ego); spondees for leading Casina into house; 882: no diaeresis; metrical uncertainty as he describes darkness?
comments_other: Ol. to audience with operam date; switch from an7 to an8 for this audience address; an8 continues through beginning of his narrative;

line_first: enim iam magis <insto>, iam adpropero, magis iam libet in Casinam inruere,
line_last: cupio illam operam seni surripere, forem obdo ne senex me opprimeret.
z_old_text: I pushed more, wanting Casina before master, enim iam magis <insto> etc.
comments_on_length: all anapests except <insto>, iam ad…(889/90) and  obdo ne (891); hiatus in891 (forem obdo);
comments_other: anapests again as Ol. presses Casina (enim iam magis <insto> etc.)875-891: very effective meter for meaning: anapest7 for exciting start, switch to an8 for beginning of story, slowing down with spondees as he gets started with Casina; cretics for attempted seduction, spondaic closure at rejection (888a), back to anapests 889/890 one verse

OL. fateor.  SEN. quid fit?; 725: shorts and hiatus (after tu) underline OL.s exasperation: OL. tu amas, ego esurio et sitio.

line_first: perii hercle ego miser; dirrumpi cantando hymenaeum licet:
line_last: SEN. di hercle me cupiunt servatum.  PAR. oboluit Casinus procul.
z_old_text: SEN. perii hercle ego miser; dirrumpi cantando hymenaeum licet:...   SEN. di hercle me cupiunt servatum.  PAR. oboluit Casinus procul.
comments_on_length: SEN. starts with shorts (perii hercle ego miser), then spondees for dirrumpi etc.; largely spondaic in next lines, as Ol notes SEN’s libido and SEN. makes pass at him; dactyls for OL’s response: di melius faciant!; 814: short for PAR (if it is PAR; Questa ad loc: sunt qui ipso Chalino iniuria tribuant): oboluit Casinus procul
comments_other: note controversy over speaker and meaning of oboluit Casinus

line_first: SEN. Pardalisca! PAR. perii! unde meae usurpant aures sonitum?
line_last: SEN. quid, periisti?  PAR. perii, et tu periisti!  SEN. a, perii, quid ita?
z_old_text: SEN. Pardalisca! PAR. perii! unde meae usurpant aures sonitum? SEN. respice modo ad me.  PAR. o ere mi... SEN. quid tibi est?  quid timida es?  PAR. perii! SEN. quid, periisti?  PAR. perii, et tu periisti!  SEN. a, perii, quid ita?
comments_on_length: numerous hiatuses; Questa ad loc: versus hiare voluit poeta quo ancillulae fictum terrorem melius effingeret; also many shorts; SEN. starts each line looking like pretty regular trochees (2 trochees start 631, trochee, anapest, beg. of  spondee 632, anapest spondee 633) Pardalisca then “messes up rhythm”: 631: tribrach and hiatus, trochee, anapest split by hiatus; 632 O surrounded by hiatuses, anapests at end; 633: tribrach, hiatus; end of 633: he does the hiatus after et tu periisti, then uses several shorts; terror has caught him, too
comments_other: Is SEN trying to bring Pardalisca back to earth with trochees from the exotic aeolic meters?

line_first: SEN. gladium ut ponat et redire me intro ut liceat.  PAR. nuntiabo.
line_last: SEN. et tu orato.  PAR. et ego orabo.  SEN. at blande orato, ut soles.  sed audin?
z_old_text: SEN. gladium ut ponat et redire me intro ut liceat.  PAR. nuntiabo. SEN. et tu orato.  PAR. et ego orabo.  SEN. at blande orato, ut soles.  sed audin?
comments_on_length: spondees in middle of 707 for orabo etc.
comments_other: SEN. asks that PA and CL plead with Casina

line_first: SEN. egone in lustra? CL. scio plus quam tu me arbitrare.  SEN. quid id est? quid [tu] scis?
line_last: CL. mades mecastor: vide palliolum ut rugat!  SEN. di me te infelicent
z_old_text: SEN. egone in lustra? CL. scio plus quam tu me arbitrare.  SEN. quid id est? quid [tu] scis? CL. te sene omnium se<num homi>nem neminem esse ignaviorem. unde is, nihili? ubi fuisti?  ubi lustratu’s? ubi bibisti? mades mecastor: vide palliolum ut rugat!  SEN. di me te infelicent
comments_on_length: 244: heavily trochaic for te sene omnium senum hominem neminem esse ignaviorem; 245: shorts for ubi’s in questions; each of three ubi’s is on ictus, as is initial unde; hiatuses after nihili and fuisti set off 1st 2 questions; 246: shorts on ictus for mades and vide, then longs for di me et te infelicent
comments_other: SEN. and CL.; she has string of accusatory questions, he has simple what do you mean questions

line_first: SEN. Pardalisca! PAR. perii! unde meae usurpant aures sonitum?
line_last: SEN. quid, periisti?  PAR. perii, et tu periisti!  SEN. a, perii, quid ita?
z_old_text: SEN. Pardalisca! PAR. perii! unde meae usurpant aures sonitum? SEN. respice modo ad me.  PAR. o ere mi... SEN. quid tibi est?  quid timida es?  PAR. perii! SEN. quid, periisti?  PAR. perii, et tu periisti!  SEN. a, perii, quid ita?
comments_on_length: numerous hiatuses; Questa ad loc: versus hiare voluit poeta quo ancillulae fictum terrorem melius effingeret; also many shorts; SEN. starts each line looking like pretty regular trochees (2 trochees start 631, trochee, anapest, beg. of  spondee 632, anapest spondee 633) Pardalisca then “messes up rhythm”: 631: tribrach and hiatus, trochee, anapest split by hiatus; 632 O surrounded by hiatuses, anapests at end; 633: tribrach, hiatus; end of 633: he does the hiatus after et tu periisti, then uses several shorts; terror has caught him, too
comments_other: Is SEN trying to bring Pardalisca back to earth with trochees from the exotic aeolic meters?

AN. quid id est?  CH. tacitu’ citius audies: ut vestem cum illo mutem et pro illo iubeam me illoc ducier.; many res throughout his account: note esp. 589 per inpluvium; 591 (shorts, then longs at end for ita feci (hiatus)—ac lubens)

CH. immo ego te obsecro hercle ut audias; continues through Ch. pondering picture of Zeus and Danae; ends with ego homuncio hoc non facerem? ego illud vero ita feci—ac lubens; important narrative in ia8

(this is a conjecture of Dziatzko)

comments_other: Syrus says to Chremes that Bacchis wants money for Antiphila, and that he will ask Menedemus to pay for her; note tr7 again in association with Bacchis; tr7 for explanation of plan that goes nowhere (because of anagnorisis in next scene); starts wtih exit of CLIT; for tr7 for plan, cf. 312-329; each of the long tr7 in this play so far has been about Bacchis (242, 312, 381, 591); Bruder 28: only place in Terence (there are 4 in Plautus) where meter in dialogue changes with exit of character

comments_on_length: 623 almost all longs (can’t tell it’s tr7 until end): caution, then shorts for conclusion in 624: facere es ausam;  626 hard to scan: trepidation;  628 longs for sic est factum; 642 shorts as Ch gets excited about girl being handed over to pimps: quid cum illis agas qui neque ius neque bonum atque aequom sciunt; then 2-syllable list in 643: meliu’ peiu’, prosit obsit;    658: many extra shorts in “where did ring come from?” There seem to be many longs in Syrus’ asides throughout (e.g., 663, 665)
comments_other: (truth about Antiphila echoes meter of falsehood about Antiphila in 591ff.); anagnorisis in tr7; includes accusations of wife and her pleas; tr7 anagnorisis framed by ia8; 1st extended tr7 not about Bacchis: previous pattern reversed when obstacle to marriage is removed, same as in Adelphoe;  important information in tr7; starts with plea

comments_on_length: 566 2 res alliteration; 568 3 res, hiatus; 570 3 res; 573 few then 574 many;  606 res for minu’ me male habet;  579 3 res in a row to start oath; 580 4 res in a row for oath; 581 no res for love; 582 3 res (nam); SOS seems to use many res throughout, PA too; but none in 596 for I don’t want people to want my death; 601-602 no res for quam fortunatu’...;  604: res for ita (cf. 579); 605: how to scan mihi and mihi?; 606 3 dactyls for mihi, minu’, male

Aul. 475, Merc. 817); emotional speech following monologue stays unaccompanied (cf. Amph. 882, Bacch. 842, Merc. 700, Stich. 655; Law 15, 51); 732-735 one line; there is an additional verse partially preserved in A.  I have counted it an dassigned it to Syra;

comments_other: Dor & Syr return; Lys mon; hell breaks loose (cook); Eu, Syr monologues; music stops for Dorippa et al.; returning prayer: stereotypical and conventional; formal and ritualistic rather than emotional (cf. Bacch. 170, Mostell. 431, Poen 950, Stich. 402; contrast Trin. 820; Law 33); complaints about domestic troubles (cf. Aul. 475, Merc. 817); emotional speech following monologue stays unaccompanied (cf. Amph. 882, Bacch. 842, Merc. 700, Stich. 655; Law 15, 51); 732-735 one line; there is an additional verse partially preserved in A.  I have counted it an dassigned it to Syra;

line_first: rem omnem tibi, Acroteleutium, tibique una, Milphidippa,
line_last: PER. ne quid, ubi miles venerit, titubetur.  AC. tu morare.
z_old_text: rem omnem tibi, Acroteleutium, tibique una, Milphidippa, domi demonstravi in ordine.  hanc fabricam fallaciasque...   PER. ne quid, ubi miles venerit, titubetur.  AC. tu morare.
comments_other: starts with entance of Acr. just as ia7 of 1st half started with entrance of Phil.; Peri, Pal, Milph, Acro plan; Milph. is on and silent; 894-895 and 939-40 are both one line; 874 names Ac. and Mil. end each half of line

line_first: MI. era, eccum praesto militem.  AC. ubi est? MI. ad laevam.  AC. video.
line_last: PA. nauclerus hicquidem est.  PY. videlicet accersit hanc iam.  PA. credo.
z_old_text: MI. era, eccum praesto militem.  AC. ubi est? MI. ad laevam.  AC. video....   PA. nauclerus hicquidem est.  PY. videlicet accersit hanc iam.  PA. credo.
comments_other: deception of Py by Acro and Mil; thus 3 central deception scenes in rising meter: Phil and Scel, Mil and Py, Acro and Py.

line_last: moderare animo, ne sis cupidus.  sed eccam ipsam, egreditur foras.

line_first: illic hinc abiit intro huc.  sed quis haec est quae me advorsum incedit?

z_old_text: illic hinc abiit intro huc.  sed quis haec est quae me advorsum incedit? SOPH. Paegnium hic quidem est. PAE.: Sophoclidisca haec peculiarest eius PAE. quo ego sum missus.  SOPH. nullus esse hodie hoc puero peior perhibetur.
closure: per end of speech end of canticum proper
comments_on_length: longs for sed quis haec est quae me advorsum incedit (does this suggest Paegnium is not really in such a hurry?); shorts for SOPH. Paegnium hic quidem est. PAE.: Sophoclidisca, then hiatus, then trochees and spondees; closure; canticum seems to speed up, then slow down at end; 200: illic one syllable (cf. Epid. 81; these lines seem especially chaotic; compare 13-16)
comments_other: last before compellabo; 3 tr8 as Soph. and Paegnium recognize each other, echoes 4 tr8 as Toxilus and Sag. recognize each other

line_first: tuum promeritumst merito ut faciam; et ut me scias esse ita facturum,

TOX. percontare ex ipsis: ipsae tibi narrabunt; 500 more shorts for dialogue

comments_on_length: mostly longs until end with quidquid erit, <te fac> iam ut scias. lines split between speakers at diaeresis except 45; similar pattern: Sag. starts second half with dactyl; 44: longs for quaesivi, nusquam repper;
comments_other: ia7 for loan

closure: per end of canticum and scene, last before ia6

comments_other: repeated return to ia7 throughout this canticum ia7 starts with Amoris vitio

comments_on_length: 210 completely regular to get us started; then 211 has substitutions for navem et mulierem; average about 1 molossus per line thereafter, also frequent resolutions; conspicuous: 215: longs for neque eis ulla ornandi, then shorts for satietas; 219-222: longs for ex industria ambae numquam concessamus / lavari aut fricari aut tergeri aut ornari / poliri expoliri, pingi fingi; et una / binae singulis quae datae ancillae nobis; 223: resolutions for operam dederunt; 224: longs for viri duo defessi; 225: shorts for apage sis; 229: longs for ornatur, lavantur, tergentur, poliuntur
comments_other: Adel. on women getting ready, us as example; uniquely unbroken string of ba4; does long string of bacchiacs reinforce that she is not really a meretrix?; I follow Questa in bracketing 218

comments_other: Following Maurach, I count only through verse 1331, assuming that text broke off in middle of this verse, before “eccum lenonem Lycum,” and that interpolators added varying announcements of pimp and then the 3 endings or parts of ending: 1. 1337-1371: complete, but in ia6 2. 1372-1397: picks up at 1315, gives soldier threatening part, then a very dramatic presentation of Lycus: goes on knees, then breaks off, where final dealing with him would have occurred 3. 1398-1422: very conciliating, human and sensitive; pimp to pay money owed without going to court  there remain 66 ia6 and 25 tr7; Lindsay’s 1331 ends edepol hic venit commodus.  Leo brackets 1328-1331; I follow Maurach P in bracketing 1328, but I keep 1329-1331 (except last part) 1330-1331 one verse

line_first: sed adire certum est hanc amatricem Africam.
line_last: AN. credo.  AGO. et ego credo. sed eccum lenonem Lycum.

comments_other: Following Maurach, I count only through verse 1331, assuming that text broke off in middle of this verse, before “eccum lenonem Lycum,” and that interpolators added varying announcements of pimp and then the 3 endings or parts of ending: 1. 1337-1371: complete, but in ia6 2. 1372-1397: picks up at 1315, gives soldier threatening part, then a very dramatic presentation of Lycus: goes on knees, then breaks off, where final dealing with him would have occurred 3. 1398-1422: very conciliating, human and sensitive; pimp to pay money owed without going to court  there remain 66 ia6 and 25 tr7; Lindsay’s 1331 ends edepol hic venit commodus.  Leo brackets 1328-1331; I follow Maurach P in bracketing 1328, but I keep 1329-1331 (except last part) 1330-1331 one verse

comments_on_length: 241: trochees for it dies, spondees for ego mi cesso; 241a: starts spondees (I prae), then Ballio says two shorts (puere), and CAL. makes anapests, picking up his previous rhythm as he urges Pseudolus to stop Ballio (heus, abit.  quin revocas); 242: Pseudolus switches to dactyls: quid properas? placide; CAL. finishes dactyl then back to anapests CAL. at prius quam abeat.; 242a mix of feet as Ballio addresses puer: quid [hoc] malum, tam placide is, puere?;  shorts of placide is contrast with content; p’s 242: on non ictus; 242a on non ictus
comments_other: trochees for motion; they will continue through 243, then switch to ba as he tries to slow BAL down; 241, 241a, 242, 242a

comments_on_length: 241: trochees for it dies, spondees for ego mi cesso; 241a: starts spondees (I prae), then Ballio says two shorts (puere), and CAL. makes anapests, picking up his previous rhythm as he urges Pseudolus to stop Ballio (heus, abit.  quin revocas); 242: Pseudolus switches to dactyls: quid properas? placide; CAL. finishes dactyl then back to anapests CAL. at prius quam abeat.; 242a mix of feet as Ballio addresses puer: quid [hoc] malum, tam placide is, puere?;  shorts of placide is contrast with content; p’s 242: on non ictus; 242a on non ictus

line_first: quia pol meo animo omnis sapientis
line_last: PAN. placet, taceo. SOR. at memineris facito.
z_old_text: starts quia pol meo animo omnis sapientis / suum officium aequom est colere et facere. / more admonishment, ends placet, taceo. SOR. at memineris facito.
comments_on_length: starts anapests: quia pol meo animo omnis sapientis, then more dactyls: suum officium aequom est colere et facere; then mix; soror finishes with anapests: nostrum officium meminisse decet; PAN. ends canticum proper with many shorts: placet, taceo.  SOR. at memineris facito;
comments_other: taceo brings change from anapests to tr7 (unless 48-57 are authentic; just possibly they are: they do not repeat what is in anapests and would follow pattern of taceo leading to ia6); would be unusual break in music to stress importance of women’s dilemma; short ia6 passage similar to what happens near end of play;  (9an4+1an4cat); but  I am not counting 48-57 there is a 45a

line_first: quia pol meo animo omnis sapientis
line_last: PAN. placet, taceo. SOR. at memineris facito.
z_old_text: starts quia pol meo animo omnis sapientis / suum officium aequom est colere et facere. / more admonishment, ends placet, taceo. SOR. at memineris facito.
comments_on_length: starts anapests: quia pol meo animo omnis sapientis, then more dactyls: suum officium aequom est colere et facere; then mix; soror finishes with anapests: nostrum officium meminisse decet; PAN. ends canticum proper with many shorts: placet, taceo.  SOR. at memineris facito;
comments_other: taceo brings change from anapests to tr7 (unless 48-57 are authentic; just possibly they are: they do not repeat what is in anapests and would follow pattern of taceo leading to ia6); would be unusual break in music to stress importance of women’s dilemma; short ia6 passage similar to what happens near end of play;  (9an4+1an4cat); but  I am not counting 48-57 there is a 45a

comments_other: Lysiteles finishes; Philto enters; Questa says could be system with no catalexis (compares Trin. 1115-1119) or structura systemi similis (cf. Pers. 171-171a); interesting that Philto should continue canticum proper; this unites father and son; reinforces unusual situation that this father and son share same moral view rather than being in opposition like most fathers and sons of comedy;  there is a 275a

comments_other: joy; echo of all the an4 in Lys’ 1st canticum; Lys’ joyful return knowing news; is there an echo here of Charmides’ anapests? or perhaps of Philto’s?

comments_other: Meg & Cal plan deception; frame for sycophant; again, no music for Megaronides: fits his sternness; there is a 788a (Leo brackets: here he is surely right, because it is a repeat of 788; I have not counted it); I follow Leo in bracketing 767;

line_first: eo mi magis lubet cum probis potius
line_last: me abs tuo conspectu occultabo.
comments_on_length: starts many shorts: eo mi magis lubet cum probis potius / quam cum improbis vivere vanidicis;  dactylic andamento when Philto enters, esp. dactyls for nec tibi ero in mora nec latebrose; then longs for conclusion: me abs tuo conspectu occultabo;
comments_other: Lysiteles finishes; Philto enters; Questa says could be system with no catalexis (compares Trin. 1115-1119) or structura systemi similis (cf. Pers. 171-171a); interesting that Philto should continue canticum proper; this unites father and son; reinforces unusual situation that this father and son share same moral view rather than being in opposition like most fathers and sons of comedy;  there is a 275a

line_first: stultus es qui facta infecta facere verbis postules.
line_last: Veneris causa adplaudite: eius haec in tutelast fabula.
z_old_text: stultus es qui facta infecta facere verbis postules....   (PHR) spectatores, bene valete, plaudite atque exsurgite.
comments_other: starts with Ast.: continues through their dialogue, then Din monologue of despair; Callicles learns truth from Ancilla and Tonstrix, Din promises to marry; Din makes deal with Phronesium; Stratophanes and Strabax fight, epilogue; all this joined in tr7; important information in tr7; I did not count 968, which appears to be a doublet of epilogue; there is an 858a; Leo brackets 797-798, but I have counted them.  Enk T follows Leo, citing Langen

comments_other: Phronesium’ s monologue, Stratophanes monologue and scene; Strat. does not change meter with his monologue; women are in control (note Cyamus does change meter at 551 with his entrance); grand procession; Lindsay brackets 487, Leo 488; one of them must be right, so I have taken one verse from Stratophanes’ count

line_last: quam mihi, qui mihimet omnia facio mala.
z_old_text: piscis ego credo, qui usque dum vivont lavant,...  quam mihi, qui mihimet omnia facio mala.—
comments_other: Din & Ast,Din mon;Phron tells Din, Din mon; music stops for Diniarchus; stays off for Phronesium (again, an exception); this will increase power of music in Phronesium’s second monologue; she is seen through Diniarchus’ eyes: his perspective so far is unaccompanied (but cf. his eavesdropping on Astaphium); she tells Diniarchus secrets about soldier; 434: emotional monologue unaccompanied; Phronesium has no monologue here; music is saved for her monologue, her real presentation to the audience; Diniarchus excluded from music, as he is excluded from Phronesium’s house

line_first: datin soleas? atque me intro actutum ducite,
line_last: ubi male accipiar mea mihi pecunia.
z_old_text: datin soleas? atque me intro actutum ducite,...  (Tru.) ubi male accipiar mea mihi pecunia.—
comments_other: Phron off; Stratophanes lament; Strabax mon; Strabax in; Truculentus seduced; music stops for soldier’s response to bad news; 3rd lover introduced; again, lover’s monologue unaccompanied: cynicism rather than romanticism; seduction unaccompanied; lack of accompaniment reinforces shockingness; permits contrast with Diniarchus’ joy; parallel’s stop in music when Diniarchus gives up on Phronesium at 322; Truc. 630: a break in the situation and consequent change in emotion (Law 9); reversal of feeling from excited dispute to calm (Law 95); 664-665 one line starts with exit of Cyamus, who started canticum proper at 551: tour de force for this actor?

comments_other: starts with Ast.: continues through their dialogue, then Din monologue of despair; Callicles learns truth from Ancilla and Tonstrix, Din promises to marry; Din makes deal with Phronesium; Stratophanes and Strabax fight, epilogue; all this joined in tr7; important information in tr7; I did not count 968, which appears to be a doublet of epilogue; there is an 858a; Leo brackets 797-798, but I have counted them. line_first: piscis ego credo, qui usque dum vivont lavant,
line_last: quam mihi, qui mihimet omnia facio mala.
z_old_text: piscis ego credo, qui usque dum vivont lavant,...  quam mihi, qui mihimet omnia facio mala.—
comments_other: Din & Ast,Din mon;Phron tells Din, Din mon; music stops for Diniarchus; stays off for Phronesium (again, an exception); this will increase power of music in Phronesium’s second monologue; she is seen through Diniarchus’ eyes: his perspective so far is unaccompanied (but cf. his eavesdropping on Astaphium); she tells Diniarchus secrets about soldier; 434: emotional monologue unaccompanied; Phronesium has no monologue here; music is saved for her monologue, her real presentation to the audience; Diniarchus excluded from music, as he is excluded from Phronesium’s house

comments_other: Phron off; Stratophanes lament; Strabax mon; Strabax in; Truculentus seduced; music stops for soldier’s response to bad news; 3rd lover introduced; again, lover’s monologue unaccompanied: cynicism rather than romanticism; seduction unaccompanied; lack of accompaniment reinforces shockingness; permits contrast with Diniarchus’ joy; parallel’s stop in music when Diniarchus gives up on Phronesium at 322; Truc. 630: a break in the situation and consequent change in emotion (Law 9); reversal of feeling from excited dispute to calm (Law 95); 664-665 one line starts with exit of Cyamus, who started canticum proper at 551: tour de force for this actor?
